item.title: What is a Consent Receipt?
item.dc:creator: iain
item.content:encoded:
A consent receipt is a consent notice that is created at the point of the consent is provided, so that consent policy and its protections can easily be captured and re-used. This enables pre and post consent  management, so all the decisions for consent don't need to be made at one time by an individual, and individual can manage consent outside of the company silo. What is very innovative about the consent receipt is that just by provisioning it,  it enables the provider to demonstrate openness and willingness by the company to self regulate. Hence demonstrating a willingness and openness to be compliant with consent.  A requirement to building trust and loyalty with brands. Benefits Individual benefit from Consent Receipts:
  • Reduces friction around personal information sharing while adding transparency.
  • Provides a record of personal data sharing transactions and associated permissions.
  • Individuals can share high value, high impact personal data in trustworthy ways  with organisations.
For  Business The Consent Receipt:
  • reduces friction
  •   improves the customer experience around personal information sharing,
  • provides the platform for consent centric, high value flows of volunteered personal information between individuals and organisations
For Regulators A consent record is proof of  good  personal information management practices within data controllers and processors. A minimum consent receipt demonstrates an open communication channel between individual and organisatons about policy.  Consent records can be used to expedite complaints, data access, and decisions for regulators.

item.title: Benefits of Consent Receipt for Individuals
item.dc:creator: iain
item.content:encoded:
Individuals benefit from Consent Receipts
Reduces friction around personal information sharing while adding transparency. Provides a record of personal data sharing transactions and associated permissions.
Individuals can share high value, high impact personal data in trustworthy waysÂ with organisations. Market forces are driving towards increased trust around personal data sharing and more data flows

item.title: Benefits of Consent Receipt
item.dc:creator: iain
item.content:encoded: Consent Receipts offer benefits to a wide array of stakeholders. The primary beneficiary is the individual in their role as provider of data to an organisation. A more detailed description of the benefits of Consent Receipts for individuals can be found at this page. In enabling and empowering individuals with Consent Receipts, we create benefit for a secondary range of stakeholders. A more detailed description of the benefits of Consent Receipts for Organisations can be found at this page.

item.title: Benefits of Consent Receipt for Organisations
item.dc:creator: iain
item.content:encoded: Managing consent, and the related permissions and preferences, is an ever growing challenge for organisations. Each new channel and customer touch-point brings increasing complexity, and the ease with which data now moves around and replicates is a challenge to all parties involved. Maintaining and refreshing consent adds further challenge, the customer or prospect does not wish to be bothered by regularly updating things that often mean very little to them, and yet has high expectations around accuracy, timeliness and relevance of messaging. Third party sharing of consented data adds yet more fuel to the fire, whether from sharer or 'shared with' perspective. And that's before we even think about the ever increasing regulatory burden emerging around consent. Something needs to change to turn the above series of pain points into a more fruitful, easier to manage area going forward. That something is the Consent Receipt. The simple act of providing a standard receipt to a data provider solidifies many aspects of the sourcing, management and use of personal data within organisations. Consider the different roles within organisations that are impacted by consent and permissions. Consent Managers The Individuals tasked with managing and using consent and related data most typically reside in the marketing function. They are at the sharp end, dealing each day with opt-ins, opt-outs, data quality, ability to contact customers and prospects, and the responses/ engagement generated from that. Improves customer experience. Provides solid  refreshable record of consent that provides a solid platform for management and use of the related personal information. Organisational processes that require access to personal information are being optimised as  more data is shared, more frequently for jointly beneficial purposes. Lawyers Simplified responses to personal information queries, reduced costs. Resources required to manage issues around personal data management and use are reduced C-Level Offers an opportunity for competitive advantage based on good practice in privacy and personal information use. Toxic data sharing processes have been eliminated along with the risks associated; organisations are driving standards upwards. Personal data management has become a key value add.

item.title: Where can I get a Consent Receipt?
item.dc:creator: iain
item.content:encoded:
At present we are very much in the prototype phase for Consent Receipts. 
We have a Consent Receipt Generator set up that allows anyone who wishes to generate a Consent Receipt in the standard alpha format to do so.

An open online notice standard is needed for accessbility to information across the internet.Â Without a dramatic increase in accessibility of critical information existing online notices and policy lack legitimacy.
A lack of standard notice also greatly effects privacy, security and economic performance of information sharing for the individual.
The call to further Open Enterprise Notice is a new effort that is currently hibernating.Â At this time if you are interested send an email to :: (pick email address)

item.title: Format Standard Summary
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded: It would be good to promote open notice as a privacy effort for consent and control of personal infromation. Notice is the focus of the format and standard but it is used in conjunciton with most privacy solutions. It spans groups. Notice is a vessel and for privacy functionality it is already a global infrastructure on the web. adoption - as notice is alerady legally to required to be as open as possible this open notice format will be aimed at adoptional and the global level as a standard way to be as open as possible. What is the best way to approach creating a standard? What could be in the standard? what are the design constraints ? Privacy Considerations Layering: 10 steps to create a multi-layered privacy Notice http://www.hunton.com/files/tbl_s47details%5Cfileupload265%5C1405%5C ten_steps_whitepaper.pdf. - Proposed EU Regulations provide a description of notice functions Looking at technically layering the notices, what policies and UI features need to be at each layer, so that this can be turned into an api for all parties to use. Should A common location for notice format als be specified in the standard? e.g. /root/notice, or is it a notice DNS server or other that is better suited to emerging infrastructure? Standard format should allow for multiple technical languages, api's for accessibility and changing formats to use to other formats. Bilateral Open Online Notice: Negotiation: Where a notice user can id/tag a notice, use for later (revoke consent), be contacted with for changes etc. where a notice user can select a choice and list a policy alternative for the service provider to consider Policy Hooks Where a policy can limit exposure/functionality to web content and internet based services based on dynamic policy interaction (e.g. UMA-for access to personal information) API-Thoughts Should a privacy api be created on the standard that is interoperable? (can this be created) This api would need to work with other api's and be plugged in at the consent level. The way to innovate with this api would be to pack the notice format with privacy features that interoperate with future information infrastructure. End Goal - Produce a format that is used for create a format that can be used to provide privacy and security assurances of the quality of notice, by proving an over all privacy considerations report for choice, fairness, security, data access, in each category Categories of privacy considerations to include: - Surveillance, Secondary Discloure, Quality Assurance, Identification Assurance, Data Minimization - Notice format can be developed to provide a systematic measure of privacy quality

item.title: Usable Transparency & Emerging Privacy Legislation
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded: (needs references, and refinement and maybe to point some specific points of harmony) Global privacy reform is happening. In the US, the Consumer Privacy Bill of Rights is an initiative to achieve transparency over privacy policies for global open internet. An activity which is needed to enable people to have control over their own personal information and identities. At the same time we need a way for safety, security, and administrative use of personal information. Â  Both of these approaches Â require the use of open notices. Notices that can be openly made and the notices that manage consent to be open and more usable. The solution for personal data control is a new use of old technology called a 'receipt'. Â It is a recordÂ ofÂ  consent transaction thatÂ tracks the purpose and the use of personal data for people, so they donâ€™t have to try to try this themselves.The receipt is a record used to track the purpos(es) we consent to in a similar way in which a regular receipt records items we purchase. While an Open Notice Registry tracks (registers) all the open policies that people have to consent too. The great thing about a consent receipt is that it is designed to carry digital trust marks, certificates, reputations (like consumer reports) and policies that provide greater trust and assurance online (and in trusted networks/federations). A consent receipt is intended Â to deliver an artefact to the data subject, providing consent. Â It use promises consistent transparency over trust and policy claims to people, where and when they need it. The Consumer Privacy Bill of Rights echoes privacy and Data Protection Reform that is on the agenda in the EU, Asia Pacific and Latin America. Regulators like the FTC are concerned that citizens are not able to see who is compliant with laws. Â At this time people are unable to Â if the service providers they are using are compliant Â (or better) with local laws. This is a huge issue for child protection, parental consent for governments around the world. Â Â COPPA has consent obligations an that are mirrored around the world. Â  Â COPPA regulation in the US mirrors in many ways EU regulation in terms of consent and notice obligations. Â These together make a very good starting pointÂ for Â conceptually building the next generation of personal data control. Overall this topic of a global standard for consent and notice is an ancient one with a glorious history that Â is inevitably is driving towards harmonisation in protocol. Â From the development and the enactment to privacy principles, the resulting regulation, and its inevitable appearance in our daily lives, notice and consent is a fundamental singnaling architecture in information basedÂ society, smart cities and spaces. Â Â The OECD has produced many reportsÂ and collaborations in this regard over the years. Â All of which is reflected in social physics work underway at MIT labs. An Open Notice is working onÂ a registry that provides consent receipts and the research funding to apply and implement the consent receipt. Â We are interested in mapping all of the specific regulations toÂ develop the policy infrastructure Â needed to understand what harmonisation would actually look like. Â Of course a project like this takes collaboration across the global Â ecosystem, there are many groups and efforts in this space which need to be invited to develop in this space. I think we are soon going to see some larger collaborations and funded projects arise in this space and their are a lot of little implementations along the way.

item.title: Benefits of Consent Receipt for Regulators
item.dc:creator: iain
item.content:encoded:
Helps illustrate and enable goodÂ personal information management practices within data controllers and processors. Provides a solid proof of compliance in a complaint.
Much less regulatory over-sight and intervention required.

item.title: Join the Working Group
item.dc:creator: iain
item.content:encoded:
The working group that is developing the Consent Receipt standard can be found at  The Kantara Initiative CISWG Wiki To join the working group:
  1. click join and agree to the IPR policy.  This is necessary as the objective of the WG is to create a standard for creating a consent receipt.
  2. Sign up to the mailing list

item.title: Benefits of Consent Receipt for Service Providers
item.dc:creator: iain
item.content:encoded:
Service providers to organisations, most notably marketing service providers, can build the Consent Receipt standard into their offerings. In doing so they support improved customer experience for customers of their clients, and maintain their own competitive position in the marketplace.
In turn, new market requirements will emerge as consent morphs into a more solid platform than it is at present. Offers a robust plug-in component that reduces friction and improves the customer experience around personal information sharing
Has become â€˜business as usualâ€™

item.title: Develop Consent Receipt's
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded: Welcome to the development page for the consent receipt. This section is currently being developed with this general outline: 1. Guide to Develop Consent 2. try the demo API - for consent receipt generator http://api.consentreceipt.org 3. use the api your self - create a consent receipt button 4. Generate  a two party Consent Receipts - Guide to intalling the API 5. Provide us with this feed back 6. Give direct input - CISWG Currently we are using  v0.7 of the consent receipt, and consent receipt generator, we call this version the MVCR (Minimum Viable Consent Receipt).

item.title: Consent Receipt: MVCR v.07 Specifcation Draft
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded: This is the latest draft of the MVCR consent receipt specification.  (note: the latest work can always be found in the Kantara Initiative github repository  https://github.com/KantaraInitiative/mvcr   KI-CISWG-Editorial-MVCR-V0_7-20150907   Version.0.7.Read.me In this version of the MVCR, there is also some  experimental components.  The first is the information sharing section, which is as yet, un-specified, along with a  temporary set of PI attributes and purposes, which can be used to test the receipt, found in the appendix of the specification.  Any implementation at this time should use their own purpose, but may find these references handy.   Note: these are in no means definitive for the specification. Current work effort status, we are developing some legal profiles, work-shopping purpose and attributes. we will also be having a receipt  design session researching design requirements, with the ideas that purpose(s) can be represented by icons and the like. Yet, the sepecification and its use to provide consent receipts make current adhesive consent practices more adhesive.

item.title: Consent Receipts for Website Logins
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded: The most common requirement for consent receipts on the Internet are for website login's. The consent receipt is rapidly becoming a tool to provide transarency over personal data sharing and consent. The laws are changing to required better consent transparency because people want to understand how their personal data is used and what they are consenting to.

item.title: What does the words Open & Notice stand for?
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded: The internet and the governance of information control is based on consent orientated framework in jurisprudence.Â Â Â  Predominately privacyÂ  legislationÂ  internationally isÂ  based on FIPP's (Fair Information Privacy Principles) in which Openness is a key principle and refers to the requirement that data control and purpose to be transparent in order to facilitate choice . This is often what is understood as fair and reasonable and why we have a global infrastructure of privacy policies and terms of use contracts. Defining Open Refers to openness principle Notice Refer to privacy and consent based policies, which are requierd to be open for informed consent to be possible.Â  This refers generally to legal requirements spelt out in privacy and data control legislation world wide. Here is a growing list of references for Openness and NoticeÂ  The Fair Information Practices â€˜s 1st principle and first line is Â â€The most fundamental principle is notice.â€ In Canada â€“ The 8th Principle of PIPEDA is Openness In the 1980 OECD Privacy Guidelines - Principle 6 is Openness In the EU Dirctive 95/46 EC - Transparency (Notice) is principle 7. In the Australia Natinal Privacy Principles 5 â€“ Notice CSA (Canadian Standards Association) Model Code For The Protection Of Personal Data 2. Notice HIPPA (Health Insurance Portability Act) Principle 4. Notice of Privacy Practices Safe Harbour Principle 1. Notice, 2. Choice Japan Personal Information Protection Act Principle 2. Provisions of Obligations â€“ 2.e Disclosure APEC Privacy Framework 2nd principle is Notice Operational Definitions of Open & Notice, From the (ISTPAAnalysisofPrivacyPrinciplesV2, 2007) Â is a good place to start for terms and definitions. â€œOpenness: Availability to individuals of the data collectorâ€™s or data userâ€™s policies and practices relating to their management of personal information; and for establishing the existence of, nature and purpose of use of personal information held about them.â€ â€œNotice: Information regarding an entityâ€™s privacy policies (personal data management) and practices (terms for management) including: definition of the personal information collected; its use (purpose specification); its disclosure to parties within or external to the entity; practices associated with the maintenance and protection of the information; options available to the data subject regarding the collectorâ€™s privacy practices; changes made to policies or practices; and information provided to data subject at designated times and under designated circumstances. â€

Â 

This is the first collaboration by the Open Notice workgroup. This diagram represents the technical components of the ecosystem mapped to some of the organisations that are working on creating greater transparency and control for people. This map, contributed by Solon Barcas of NYU, was modified by Par Lannero and presented at the W3C conference " Do Not Track & Beyond" at Berkeley University in November 2012.

item.title: Small Data - An OKNF Presentation
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded:
Recently, during big data week in London, I had a chance to present Open Notice to a meetup organised by the Open Knowledge Foundation at the Centre for Creative Collaboration in Kings Cross.
Ironically, the meme for the evening was Small Data, Ironic not only because it was Big data week. Being the last to present, I had the most time waiting to speak to decide what to speak about. Just a few minutes before I stood up to talk about Open Notice it occurred to me that Privacy Policies, Terms of Service, Copyright Licenses, Cookie Policies, etc, these are great examples of Small Data.
So, I stood up and started the presentation by introducing myself and the Open Notice website. I then accused the audience of lying, before asking when the last time someone in the room (who isnt a lawyer) read a TOS, PP, Cookie Policies, before they agree to provide their (little data) to a company on the internet?
I then pointed out that this is a big problem, because, where does big data come from? It often comes from us agreeing to give our small data to someone else, like a company, to manage.
I explained that:
At this time, privacy policies, terms of services, licensing, copyright, they are all closed. They represent closed data, and that we (the service users) are ourselves hindered in wheeling our identities(Small Data) because each company has their own, bespoke policies that we all need to read and understand. The data in the notices are required by all companies and these notices should be open and provisioned in a standard way so that people use them.
I then presented the slide to introduce member's efforts like Ghostery, TOS;DR, Privacy Choice, TOSSOS, Docracy, EULA, Privowny, Disconnect Me, INformation Sharing Work Group, Common Terms, Customer Commons etc. All, efforts which are working hard to develop tools of transparency and open up the usability of policies so that they can be more useful. "
With new laws being proposed, and greater control and use of ones own data is becoming a priority for, people economics alone can explain why closed notices need to be open. Standards are needed so that people have a minimum level of transparency over policies and a minimum level of trusted usability. Not only is this required throughout the life time of the transaction, it is a requirement for informed consent, so that these terms can be binding.
It no longer makes economic sense to lock people's data in corporate silo's, to stop the flow of personal information control. This type of business is outdated. People will want to control their experiences. At a minimum it makes good business sense that there be some common public structure to facilitate the usefulness of these notices, both commercially and socially.
Bottom line, these closed policies mean personal data is not flowing as it is trapped in corporate silos. This stops people from self advertising.
Then I mentioned that we are looking for volunteers. :-)
Mark Lizar Open Notice Co-ordinator

item.title: Announcing: Data Privacy Legal Hack-A-Thon Feb 8th & 9th 2014
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded:
Â Data Privacy Legal Hack-A-thon

This is an unprecedented year documenting ourÂ loss of Privacy. Never before have we needed to stand up and team up to do something about it. Â Â In honour of Privacy Day, the Legal Hackers are leading the charge to do something about it, inspiring a two-day international Data Privacy Legal Hackathon.Â This is no ordinary event. Instead of talking about creating privacy tools in theory, the Data Privacy Legal Hackathon is about action! A call to action for tech & legal innovators who want to make a difference! We are happy to announce a Data Privacy Legal Hackathon and invite the Kantara Community to get involved and participate. Â We are involvedÂ in not only hosting Â aÂ Pre-Hackathon ProjectÂ to create a Legal Map for consent laws across jurisdictions, but the CISWG will also be posting a project for theÂ Consent Receipt ScenarioÂ that is posted in on the ISWG wiki. The intention is to hack Open Notice with a Common Legal Map to create consent receipts that enable â€˜customisers' to control personal informationÂ If you would like to get involved in the hackathon, show your support, or help build the consent receipt infrastructure please get involved right away -- you can get intouch with Mark (dot) Lizar (at)gmail (dot) com, Hodder (at) gmail (dot) com, or join the group pages that are in links below. Across three locations on February 8th & 9th, 2014, get your Eventbrite Tickets Here: *Â New York CityÂ *Â London, UKÂ * San Francisco* http://legalhackers.org/privacyhack2014/ This two-day event aims to mix the tech and legal scenes with people and companies that want to champion personal data privacy. Â Â Connecting entrepreneurs, developers, product makers, legal scholars, lawyers, and investors. Each location will host a two-dayÂ â€œjudgedâ€Â hacking competition with a prize awarding finale, followed by an after-party to celebrate the event. The Main Themes to The Hackathon Are:
  • Crossing the Pond Hack
  • Do Not Track Hack
  • Anti-Surveillance & Transparency Hacks
  • Privacy Policy Hack
  • Revenge Porn Hack
There are pre-hackathon projects and activities. Join theÂ HackerleagueÂ to participate in these efforts and list your hack:
  • AÂ Consent Legal Map & Schema ProjectÂ to create a legal map of the consent laws as a legal hackers tool for the event and projects posted at the event (many volunteers needed)
  • Brainstorming List of HacksÂ - Add your ideas
  • Share Tech and LinksÂ Page - Share your Knowledge
  • HacksÂ (Project) Page - Propose or Join a project
  • IRC Channel for Discussion
Sponsorship Is Available & Needed Any organization or company seeking to show active support for data privacy and privacy technologies is invited to get involved.
  • Sponsor:Â  prizes, food and event costs by becoming a Platinum, Gold or Silver Sponsor
  • Participate:Â  at the event by leading or joining a hack project
  • Mentor:Â  projects or topics that arise for teams, and share your expertise.
  Contact NYC sponsorship:Â Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Phil Weiss email or @philwdjjd Contact Bay Area sponsorship:Â Â  Â Â Mary Hodder - Â Hodder (at) gmail (dot) comÂ Â -Â Â Phone: 510 701 1975 Contact London sponsorship:Â Â  Â  Â  Â Mark Lizar - Mark (dot) Lizar (at)gmail (dot) comÂ Â -Â Phone: +44 02081237426 -Â @smarthart

item.title: Open Notice Update: VRM & Pre Hack Challenge
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded: Hello Everyone, The momentum behind this event is now really building up. We have invited the VRM & Personal Cloud Community lists Â to partake in the Hackathon and work with the consent receipt scenarioÂ at CISWG.Â We are very much hoping the Open Notice community and the VRM community will jump on board to support this event. See below an excerpt from our post to the Personal Cloud and VRM ListÂ fromÂ Mary Hoder & I, as Coordinators of the Open Notice Initiative and CISWG. " As people may or may not be aware the newly namedÂ Consent and Information Sharing Working Group (CISWG)Â is a VRM initiated, Personal Cloud Orientated Work Group that has been working away over the last few years on personal information sharing. Â  This effort first began gestating at Identity Commons when (VRM was still known as a â€œred dotâ€) and today this effort is very much aimed at bridging communities with tools that can really make a difference in this space. The CISWG and Open Notice Initiative are co-hosting two of the hackathon locations (London and Mountain View) with Phil Weiss from the New York Legal Hackers and Mary from Customer Commons. The aim of this announcement is to fire up a call to action to legally hack data privacy. We all know it's past time to collaborate and start doing something about the state of privacy and personal data, including the notice and consent work we propose. As apart of this project the CISWG is sponsoring aÂ pre-hackathon project to create a Legal MapÂ for hackers to use at the event inspired by the Open Notice initiative. Â  We are also working to propose a project based on a CISWG use case called theÂ Consent Receipt Scenario. The intention is to hack Open Notice with a Common Legal Map to create consent receipts that projects Â on this list can use to enable â€˜customisers' to control personal information. If you would like to get involved in the hackathon, show your support, or help build the consent receipt infrastructure please get involved -- you can email Mark Lizar, or Mary Hodder, or join the group pages that are in links above. Â (more details at http://legalhackers.org/privacyhack2014/" Mark Lizar & Mary Hodder Hackathon Co-Ordinators

item.title: Hackathon Update - Winners
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded:
We created history last weekend (Feb 8/9 2014)

A community interested in developing personal data control came together, hacked all weekend long and initiated project hacks, so that we evolve the freedom to control our own data. Â the ability to control our own data is effectively a way to save the free internet and the freedom to have privacy in the future. This event has really started something, the scale and size of this first event was remarkable. Â  Mary Hodder, and I (Mark Lizar) got involved exactly 30 days before the event and if it wasn't for the huge out-pouring of support Â could never of happened. Thank you so much everyone who is involved! With a special thanks to Judi Clark for rejoining the CISWG and helping make the San Francisco event a massive success. We had some great visitors, one of which was a cameo of Kantara's very own Eve Maler talking about consent. (video link here) All of the projects are great, very educational, some amazing effort and work went into the projects.  

The Three Winning projectsÂ 

  1. London - Consent Receipt RequestÂ -Â Presented by Reuben Binns & Valentino Spataro
  2. New York - Ghost Drop -Â Presented byÂ Max Giraldo
  3. San Francisco - Privacy Visualisation -Â Presented by Nick DotyÂ  Â 
A full list of projects presented can be found on hackerleague.orgÂ

item.title: Data Privacy Legal Hackathon London Report
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded: A Data Privacy Legal HackathonÂ was held 8-9 February 2014, inÂ Brooklyn, NY,San Francisco,Â London, andÂ online. With a Chat with EveÂ Maler also posted. We have a best of show currently underway with announcement of the winner by next monday 17th of February, 2014. This past weekend in London, lawyers, technologists and privacy advocates got together at the Centre for Creative Collaboration to prototype new tools for data privacy. Throughout the weekend we had a live video link to keep us in touch across all three time zones. Despite the many things that could have gone wrong, the remote collaboration went surprisingly smoothly, thanks to the technical teams on the ground at each event. This success was also thanks to some careful programming as part of an experiment in distributed live events conducted by Dazza Greenwood at the MIT Human Dynamics lab. We had three prizes: 1st Prize Â£500.00 Sponsored by Mandril, 2nd Prize - Github (1 Year), Â 3rd Prize - GitHub (6 Months) London Presentations is all captured on Youtube here ( 3rd Place Winner: Objective was to prototype a notice system forÂ retailers that people control and trust. The recent media furore over shopping malls tracking customers as they move around stores(see <>) demonstrates the need for an opt-out system. The team developed the backend to a smartphone-based Â notice system whereby a secure third party can Â provide a digital sign (or notice) as required by EU law of the tracking technologies involved. Â What was built acts as a preference back end. Â Their preferences are passed on to the operators of tracking software via an intermediary service, who ensures that the tracking notices have a secure backend. Â  As well as helping individuals say 'no' to certain kinds of tracking, the system incentivises companies to participate by enabling them to engage the individual in a way directed by the customer and remove friction from Â the 'customer experience' in a way the customer trusts. Combined with other technologies this can greatly increase the experience of the person interacting not only in commerce but with sensor driven physical spaces. Â Won a GitHub certificate. (2nd Place Winner) : The GeoCrunch team, comprising a lawyer and a computer scientist, created a tool to expose how location data is often 'overshared' on social networks like Twitter and Foursquare. While geotagging tweets can provide helpful information about context, it also means anyone can see where a user is at the time. Unscrupulous actors could use this information in scary ways - from stalking the user to burgling their empty home. Several similar tools have been built in order to raise public awareness and encourage better privacy practices, but ended up being used against people in the very ways they warned about. Geocrunch elegantly avoids that problem by using the Twitter authentication to restrict displays of geotagged tweets to either your own or a random Twitter user. (1st Place Winner) The 'Consent Receipt Request' team Â developed a simple prototype for a tool to keep track of all the privacy policies and terms of service you agree to online. Anytime you don't understand them (or don't have time to read them), it generates an email request to the company asking for a simplified version. The request also automatically references any legal requirements for notice and consent that exist in that company's jurisdiction. In addition, if the user opts-in, they can share a copy of their request and the company's response with our database, so we can begin to build a repository of simplified privacy notices and terms of service. This hack is app that not only test the legal premise involved in the Consent Map but provide a useful service to people who actually want to know how many companies they have consented too. The esteemed panel of judges included Dr. Ian Brown (Oxford Internet Institute), Dr. Ian Walden (Queen Mary University), John Cummings (Innovation Partners), Stefan Magdalinski (Mydex), and Wilfried De Wever â€“ Senior Justice Adviser / Justice Investment Program Manager (HiiL). They had a tough time deciding on a winner, but in the end the Consent Receipt team got lucky and took home the prize. Reuben,   Special thanks to all the Â event sponsors: Organisers Legal Hackers & Open Notice Platinum Sponsors Mozilla, Clio, Kelley & Drye Gold Mandrill,Â C4CC, Silver GitHub,Â Docracy Special Thanks to all of the Support TOS;Dr, Customer Commons, Â Open Knowledge Foundation, Â Institute for Innovation & Law, Common Terms, Customers Voice

item.title: History of the Consent Receipt
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded: The Consent Receipt project evolved out of work completed through the Open Notice Initiative. The Open Notice: A Call for Collaboration that wasÂ presentedÂ at the 2012Â W3C Conference at UC Berkeley. As momentum grew, individuals and projects focused on personal data control came together and created a 'Work Item' seeking to establish standards to fix the 'Biggest Lieâ€™ on the internet (an effort started by Par Lanero - Common Terms) which is the lie we commit when we agree to policies we havent read. . Our proposal to fix this lie has developed into the Consent Receipt specification at the Consent and Information Sharing Work Group (CISWG) at the Kantara Initiative, IEEE-ISTO. The Consent Receipt standard specification is a common format for recording consent transactions, which include tracking consent to policies and agreements made in exchange for personal data in a human, machine-readable and legal format. The Consent Receipt is designed to provide a record of a consent agreement, which can be used with services that help people see, manage, and control their personal data. The Consent Receipt reflects the interests of collaborating individuals and projects at ONI: privacy protection, privacy icons and trust marks, short notices and streamlined terms for privacy, systemic licenses, and more. The field is growing rapidly and there are numerous projects seeking to develop technical ways to control personal data who will benefit from integrating the Consent Receipt specification. The Consent Receipt is designed as a tool that can be used by all stakeholders of personal data control, including individuals, businesses and regulators. The Consent Receipt is also relevant and usable by projects in the field seeking to deliver their trust enhancing services directly to end-users. In turn, end users are able to use the Consent Receipt with any of services that collect their personal data. Much like a commercial receipt, the Consent Receipt records transactions of personal data and offers individual consumers a manner of seeing all transactions and managing post-consent personal data control. The Consent Receipt may contain different icon systems, reputation services, trust frameworks, and trust marks. It is intended to deliver the services a user needs to make informed decisions about trust and personal data use. The Consent Receipt is intended to enable collaboration, inter-operability, and an open market for personal data control, privacy, and security. The issues presented here are not small. There is no single person, company or even country that can solve the challenges posed to personal data control in todayâ€™s online reality. Yet what the Consent Receipt proposes â€“ in its most ambitious form â€“ will create and enable a market place for personal data control.

item.title: Response to the ICOâ€™s Call for Comments for Privacy Notice Code of Practice Nov-2013
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded: This was submitted to the Information Commissioners Office in the UK in Nov-2013. To view actual submission -Â ICO- Code Comments-29-11-2013 ***** In response to the ICOâ€™s Call for Comments for Privacy Notice Code of Practice Nov-2013 We are writing this on behalf of the Open Notice community ( and the Information sharing Work Group at the Kantara Initiative). We work with and are comprised of several organizations and projects that are working to evolve online privacy notices and terms-of-service infrastructure at Kantara. The Kantara Initiative is a non-profit professional association dedicated to advancing technical and legal innovation related to digital identity management. Several recommendations for best practice have already come out of our work which will help inform the ICO's revised Privacy Notices Code of Practice. We have noticed that this code of practices puts a tremendous onus on organisations to "make people understand" and this limits the meaning that this has for people. There are many known issues with use of privacy policy notices that the new code of practice could consider including. We hope that future guidance allows for more proportional use of policy notice and preferences for people to better control the use of personal information. Issues of fairness identified that should be considered: Companies range in size and resource and some would find it a great expense to have suitable notice for managing services with third parties across jurisdictions. Â E.g. Using Safe Harbour. People are unduly burdened with the responsibility of knowing all the policies of every service independently and this would costs people 76 work days a year to just read privacy policies personally (Aleecia M. McDonald and Lorrie Faith Cranor). People are unable to manage policy preferences easily post consent without logging in to every service or writing a letter Standard access rights are custom for each organisations who have the cost burden of providing infrastructure for managing personal information preferences and requests. People often have to deal with multiple policies when engaging in any transaction online not just one policy Organisations have different notice and consent rules depending on the jurisdiction and type of personal information involved There are currently limited ways for people to compare policies and check and see if their data is in fact used the way as proscribed in policy as suggested in the conclusion of the code. Suggestions In the call for comments we noticed that the ICOâ€™s code is based on fairness: The current code mentions that Fairness has two main elements Using information in a way that people would reasonably expect and in a way that is fair. Ensuring people know how their information will be used, for example by providing a privacy notice or publishing it on your website. A third element should be considered 3. Privacy policies should be as open as possible to encourage people to manage their own information and preferences. The current code mentions the importance of keeping the notice up to date, but does not recommend any means to inform affected individuals about updates and changes to privacy practices. Â Â Privacy Notices are not yet open. The Format of Privacy Policies The layered approach covered on page 17 encourages a more open and responsive approach to preference management. Â This coincides with other efforts like the National Telecommunication and Information Administration short notices code of practice, which aim to prescribe layer notices for mobile. Page 12 of the current code states that 'it's a lot easier to actively communicate a privacy notice in an online context than in a 'bricks and mortar' one. Â Â Advocating for the adoption digital ways of providing policy would be appreciated. Â Supporting the adoption of common identifiers and policy discovery practices is very high on various agendas that we are working with. Â Technically keeping a record or permanent link to governing policies and personal preferences is an area of the personal data ecosystem that is rapidly developing. At present, several third parties in the Open Notice community provide services by recording/scraping website policies and sites. Â A great example is that of TOS;Dr (Terms Of Service Did Not Read), Ghostery and Mozillaâ€™s own browser plugin, Lightbeam. Many projects range from tracking cookies, track terms of service and tracking privacy policies, all all aim to help people understand and better use policy in more meaningful ways. Visibility of Privacy Policy Privacy notices on websites can be more or less visible. Organisations should follow best practices by providing a consistent, legible URI to the notice, and link to it in a standard, prominent place on the website. Projects like Common Terms and IusOnsDemand help companies codify their information to provide layered notices. Â Emerging best practices for preferences should also be encouraged, projects like Customer Commons and the Customerâ€™s Voice are working to help companies find low cost ways for people to engage more actively. Â The URI or web address. should be concise and should not change or break. For guidance on emerging best practice for URI's, see http://warpspire.com/posts/url-design/ or http://www.w3.org/TR/cooluris/, this area is about to become much more important. Services like these l ensure that individuals who read the privacy policy and bookmark it for reference will be able to reliably return to it at a later date. It also means third-party tools which help individuals understand and manage privacy policies can reliably access the policies for assessment in the future. Finding a Balance The ICO has indicated that: â€œWeâ€™re keen to get the balance right between clear, general guidance and making sure the guidance works for new technologies.â€ Using Policy Post Consent Page 10, consent raises important recommendations on best practices for obtaining consent. However it is currently silent on providing options and information related to withdrawing or managing consent. Â When a privacy policy involves asking for consent, opt-in or opt-out from the individual, a helpful best practice would be to provide a 'consent receipt' to the user. This would provide a record to the individual about what they have agreed to and when. It also helps establish the state of the policy at the time at which the individual consented to help people with vendor relationship management. Individuals can maintain a log of their consent receipts, aided by their web browsers or other third party services. These receipts could be useful to make web experience more responsive. Â If also analysed and reviewed they inform individuals who may wish to change sharing preferences and even withdraw their consent at a later date or in context. Page 13 of the code indicates when to actively communicate privacy notice. We recommend that publishing policies on the internet be a recommended practice. Machine Readable Privacy Policy While no widely-adopted standard for machine-readable privacy policies exists at the time of writing, a number of organisations are involved in standard-setting activity for this purpose. Common Terms is a project which helps companies break their notices down into layers, the consistent ability to discover policy and its changes is very important for projects to provide value. Proactive organisations designing or updating their privacy policies should stay informed of developments in this area and adopt best practices if and when they become established. The context of the notice should be made clear, i.e. which activities on which platforms, services or parts of the website are covered by the policy.What the jurisdiction is of the policy provider, if sensitive data is used, and a way to easily manage these in the future. Sharing Information â€œSharing Informationâ€, found on page 14, Â is one of the most difficult areas to negotiate in privacy, notice and consent. Â Keeping a an active list of sharing practices is a difficult task. Â An alternative would be to encourage people to manage their own preferences. Â For example, Do Not Track is permission that people set at the browser which website can use to make policy notices more responsive. In Summary The conclusion of the code of practice, on page 15, indicates that, if there is a difference, (between the purpose people were told when providing personal information and the organization's intended use) people should be informed. Â Â As policies are not yet found in a common locations and in a machine readable manner online this is a challenge we hope this new code will help address. Best Regards, Open Notice & The Kantara Initiative: Consent Information Sharing Work Group Coordinators Mark Lizar Reuben Binns Iain Henderson Par Lannero Hugo Roy Mary Hodder Valentino Spataro

item.title: Kantara CISWG Release v0.6 of the Consent Receipt
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded: Open Notice has partneredÂ  with the Kantara Initiative'sÂ  "Consent & Information Sharing Work Group" (CISWG), where we are working on a standard consent format to Open Consent Policies so people can manage and control their own data though consent management.Â Â  This consent receipt specification pulls the relevant pieces of information from a companies privacy policy and displays them in a simplified short privacy and terms notice called a â€˜Consent Receiptâ€™. Privacy and terms of use policy infrastructures on the Internet is broken.Â  We click on buttons to provide consent without reading the policies because they changed hasve littile meaning. Fixing this broken aspect of digital life is a critical component to safeguarding freedom. Protecting privacy for individuals as well as companies and institutions is a critical stepping stone to enabling personal data control and trust online. Kantara Initiative is a business acceleration organization that is a global, open, and transparent community stakeholder experts representing enterprise deployers, mobile operators, service providers, eGovernment agencies, IT vendors, and consumer electronics vendors. Kantara Initiative Members collaboratively harmonize and innovate to solve global technical and policy interoperability challenges. As a result we are proud to be a contributing member of the Kantara Initiative

item.title: Paper: Open Notice-A Call For Collaboration.
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded:
Paper: Open Notice-A Call For Collaboration. November 15th, 2012. This paper and presentation outlines a framework for collaboration amongst industry, academics, lawyers and other interested parties. http://www.w3.org/2012/dnt-ws/position-papers/23.pdf PresentedÂ  on Nov 25th, 2012 at University of Berkeley, California at the W3C workshop Do Not Track, and Beyond, by Mark Lizar and Ashkan Soltani.  

Opening up the Online Notice Infrastructure An â€˜Open Noticeâ€™ Call For Collaboration

Abstract

Many people who use the web express concern about both the increasing
amounts of their personal data being collected online and the terms to which
they agree. The existing global infrastructure for managing data and terms relies
heavily on the use of â€˜noticesâ€™, and these come from the data collector, rather
than from the individual. Notices are the legal regulatory mechanisms that refer
to privacy policies and terms of service. This system of notices is unfit for use
in the contemporary digital context. The notices are often unreadable, unclear,
and not useful in practice. They provide limited guidance for people and few
benefits to the companies and organisations who issue them. Open Notice is an
effort that calls for an open, global, and public infrastructure for legally
required, digitally necessary consent-based notices. The Open Notice effort
seeks to foster collaboration among the various projects working on these
problems around the world. This paper outlines a framework for greater multi-
stakeholder collaboration between these projects, regulators, and governments,
with the aim of creating an open and global notice infrastructure.

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded:
Title: Open Notice Initiative Web Privacy Statement Date: July 26, 2014 Revision: 1.0 Keywords: Privacy, "Open Notice"
# Open Notice Web Privacy Statement
## Summary
> This summary should be on the page or pop up where people click their consent
The Open Notice site will respect your privacy as much as possible. You should know that we do use cookies, but that other than technical data, no information that you give us about yourself will be shared with third parties. However, your browser may record that you have been at this site, and share that information on other sites.
## Collecting information from or about you
There are only two purposes for which we collect information about your or your browser when you visit our site; to operate a web service and to fulfill requests from you. It is the case that when you visit a web site, your browser exchanges information with our web servers. Some of that information is retained in web server logs. We collect, use, and retain as little of that as possible for as short a time as is consistent with providing a reliable web service. Other than this, we will only collect information from you or about you when we tell you that we are doing so. For example, we might ask for you contact information for a mailing list, or to become a supporter of the Open Notice Initiative, or for a petition and so on.
**Cookies**: *Our site uses cookies for statisticalÂ web traffic analysis.*
## Using information from or about you
We use the information collected by the web server to maintain the web server and to troubleshoot any issues that may arise. That includes aggregate information about how people found our web site, what kind of browsers they are using, and other similar analytics. We use other information that you give us only for the purposes we identified at the time that we collected it.
## Disclosing information about you
We will only do this with your explicit permission. For example, if we run a petition campaign we might ask you if its OK to publish your name. We do analyze information about our web traffic using a third party service. We do our best to ensure that we provide the minimum information necessary to understand our web traffic, and that as much of the information as is possible is de-identified or aggregated, but you should know that this kind of service may be regarded as a disclosure of personal information in many jurisdictions.
You should also know that if we are asked for information from a legal authority we will ask for a warrant or equivalent instrument, but that if there is a legal authority for the information requested we will comply with the law.
## Retaining information about you
We will keep server logs for the minimum time that our service provider and technical best practices allow. Our target is 30 day retention but we cannot guarantee that. We will keep the information that you have provided us for as long as it is necessary for the purpose you provided it. For example, if you have given us your contact information to keep in contact with you, we will keep that informatin and continue to use it until you tell us to stop. For specific campaigns, we will keep the information collected for the duration of the campaign, plus one year.
## Questions and complaints
If you have any concerns or complaints please send an email to <privacy@opennotice.org>.

item.title: Closed Consent
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded:
There is no common consent record format.
Information sharing is a complex issue for organizations that require consent for the collection of personal information.Â Legal obligations require privacy policies that reflect how personal information may be collected, used, disclosed, retained and disposed of or deleted.
Each organization has their own best practices, policy structures and policy formats. This results in a closed (or 'siloed') type of transparency, that violates theÂ Openness (transparency and notice) privacy principles, is very costly to manage for all stakeholders and very difficult to regulate effectively. This is compounded by each organization posting their policies in different locations, while frequently changing not only the content but also the URI of the policies.
The result is the current static and binary notice and consent infrastructure that is regulated, yet neither usable nor suitable for its intended purposes. An individual is asked to perform beyond what is reasonable in the current context.Â Each individual is expected to understand what information is being collected about them, how it will be used and for what purposes, with which types of entities their information will be shared and to understand and manage the consequences long past the first point of consent. All of this is without a record or the ability to manage consent independently out of context. Meanwhile, in context, people are expected to read all policies, keep track of all active consents, so as to be informed when making new consent agreements.
 
Information sharing is dramatically increasing, as a result, the capacity for people to manage information sharing also needs to increase. A specification for aÂ core viable consent (or authorisation) will address specific jurisdictional requirements and provide a useful framework for developing compliance with ISO 29100 and other trust standards and frameworks.
Individuals' capacity to manage privacy is increased if they are able to aggregate and manage consent after it is provisioned.Â Digital consent records, which in this specification is called a consent receipt, enable people to manage information sharing relationships. Organizations can use these receipts to reduce friction and streamline the consent experience.
The core receipt specification addresses general, or regulatory, consent requirements. Consent receipts additionally become more useful as a channel for trust services, trust networks, identity federations, trust marks, privacy icons, standards, assurances, certifications and self asserted community and industry reputations.
# Stakeholders
There are three general stakeholder audiences for the MVCR which are referenced through this specification:
1. People: People receive the consent receipt and may use this to independently track consent and manage terms of sharing personal information.
2. Organizations: Organizations provide consent receipts when they obtain or assume consent to collect personal information.
3. Regulators - (privacy and data protection enforcement) Regulators include but aren't limited to the FTC in the USA, the Canadian Federal and Provincial Privacy Commissioners, the EU Data Protection Regulators. Regulators provide public processes for administration and enforcement of regulation in regards to notice and consent requirements
In summary, this MVCR receipt specification addresses the requirements of these three stakeholder groups with the aim to provide a self-regulatory market trust tool that organizations will implement, people can use, and regulators can enforce.

item.title: Consent Is A Critical Component of Trust
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded: By Mark Lizar, CISWG Co-Chair, Kantara Initiative Re-posted from Internet Technical Advisory Committee In a day and age where sharing personal data is increasingly central to our social practices online and a requirement for the use of many services and applications, the capacity for users to understand and manage the data they share online is more important than ever. Key to this is the notion of consent, which means that people explicitly agree to sharing, but at this time people can’t independently track or control sharing using policies. In this regard, Kantara Initiative’s Consent & Information Sharing Work Group (CISWG) is proud to announce our work on a Consent Receipt open standard. The Consent Receipt seeks to increase personal data control and transparency by increasing the capacity for people to track and manage data sharing relationships. We can build stronger trust in today’s digitally driven economy by upgrading the digital consent and “I agree” buttons on and off the Internet so that they provide users with a record of what personal information they have shared with a particular service. The Consent Receipt serves people, organizations, and governments by addressing a lack of user trust. A Special Eurobarometer research report, released in June 2015, indicated a strong demand for consent, greater transparency, and more personal data control. This report is generated from a survey completed in March 2015. Approximately 28,000 respondents from different social and demographic groups were interviewed. Sample quotes from the report reveal the current paradox: users are expected to provide consent with little or no information regarding what data they have consented to release. “Nearly seven out of ten people (69%) say that their explicit approval should be required in all cases “. “Yet only Only one fifth of respondents say they are always informed about the conditions of data collection and its potential uses when they are asked to provide personal information online.” “Two-thirds of respondents (67%) say that they find privacy statements too long to read, while nearly four out of ten (38%) find them unclear or too difficult to understand.” The Challenge – Usable and meaningful consent is obstructed by outdated practices and infrastructure. Policies and consent management today are having the effect of obscuring personal data control and eroding trust and innovation in the digital economy. The Solution – A Consent Receipt is designed to solve this issue by increasing the capacity for people to manage personal information sharing. The development of a common way to record consent enables privacy policies to be layered, making them machine and human readable. A standardized Consent Receipt effectively enables consent to be managed independently of service providers while affording the opportunity to make consent a positive customer experience. Kantara Initiative is a participating Member of the OECD-ITAC. If you would like to learn more about the Consent Receipt work and how your organization can contribute or adopt please visit: http://bit.ly/ciswg

item.title: Consent Receipts: Safe Harbour through Personal Data Control
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded: (image and analytical background on Safe Harbor are in part inspired by  an excellent business analysis & summary  posted by Sotiris Spyrou & Posted in: Business, Cloud Data, SEO News.) One of the biggest issues with moving data across jurisdictions is the different laws.  This is in addition to the complexity of difference cultures and different contexts that create expectations of data use.  This is why data protection and privacy in the context of cross border data transfers is so difficult. A preferred way to expedite data transfers is for people to control their own data and to consent to its access, rather than only its transfer. A consent receipt is like a reverse (VRM) cookie, its a record that people get to track organisations and what they share about them.  It collects the identity attributes that are provided, the purpose they are provided for and who they are shared with.  The Consent Receipt can also carry assurances, trust marks, security promises and even reputations. Combined with UMA, a consent receipt is a tool to show how personal control over data means that it can stay in a jurisdiction, and be shared  with others. In essence people can control access to data and create their own Safe Harbor to transfer data across borders. Regardless of who the data controller is, a key benefit of a consent receipt for organizations is the ability to add, record and provide jurisdiction specific  notice requirements to a consent notice.  Demonstrating compliance (or not) by the notices provided with the privacy policy for sharing and data use.   Combined with model contract clauses, which are used to assure liability and define data controls, consent receipts address Privacy Policies while model contracts address Terms of Use. In the EU, notice and consent is required for all personal data collection and sharing.  In the US, explicit notices are required for consent for sensitive data.  Data covered by federal laws like COPPA, GBLA, HIPPA, and the like. In every jurisdiction sensitive data comes with specific, legally defined, notice requirements, that are localized.  All sensitive personal data transfer requires explicit consent and notice that are intended to assure informed consent.   It is for this reason that a consent receipt has been designed to highlight sensitive data, both what an individual considers sensitive and what the law considers sensitive, so that PII can be shared. If an organisation doesn’t meet legal notice requirements across jurisdictions, then it doesn’t matter what model contract clauses are used, the consent is not informed and compliant for sensitive data collection and sharing.  In fact, model clauses can become a source of toxic liability and can be used to hold the data controller or processors liable. (which builds trust)

item.title: Benefits of Consent Receipt for Organisations
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded: by Iain Henderson Managing consent, and the related permissions and preferences, is an ever growing challenge for organisations. Each new channel and customer touch-point brings increasing complexity, and the ease with which data now moves around and replicates is a challenge to all parties involved. Maintaining and refreshing consent adds further challenge, the customer or prospect does not wish to be bothered by regularly updating things that often mean very little to them, and yet has high expectations around accuracy, timeliness and relevance of messaging. Third party sharing of consented data adds yet more fuel to the fire, whether from sharer or ‘shared with’ perspective. And that’s before we even think about the ever increasing regulatory burden emerging around consent. Something needs to change to turn the above series of pain points into a more fruitful, easier to manage area going forward. That something is the Consent Receipt. The simple act of providing a standard receipt to a data provider solidifies many aspects of the sourcing, management and use of personal data within organisations. Consider the different roles within organisations that are impacted by consent and permissions. Consent Managers The Individuals tasked with managing and using consent and related data most typically reside in the marketing function. They are at the sharp end, dealing each day with opt-ins, opt-outs, data quality, ability to contact customers and prospects, and the responses/ engagement generated from that. Improves customer experience. Provides solid  refreshable record of consent that provides a solid platform for management and use of the related personal information. Organisational processes that require access to personal information are being optimised as  more data is shared, more frequently for jointly beneficial purposes. Lawyers Simplified responses to personal information queries, reduced costs. Resources required to manage issues around personal data management and use are reduced C-Level Offers an opportunity for competitive advantage based on good practice in privacy and personal information use. Toxic data sharing processes have been eliminated along with the risks associated; organisations are driving standards upwards. Personal data management has become a key value add.

item.title: Consent Receipt Presentation at IIW
item.dc:creator: mark
item.content:encoded: Presented Oct 26,2016 by John Wunderlich, This Introduction to the MVCR (Minimum Viable Consent Receipt) explains how a consent receipt is an innovative consent notice and  solves challenges that prevent people from sharing high value, personal information.
